Browse here.Article contentThat picture is improving in B.C. as well, but the proportion of household income eaten up by housing costs remains high.Article contentIt’s at 89.2 per cent for Vancouver, down from more than 100 per cent in 2024. In Victoria, the affordability measure rose slightly to 69 per cent, but is down from a high of 80 per cent in 2024.Article contentThat’s much higher than in places like Calgary (40.9 per cent), Edmonton (32.2 per cent), Montreal (48.4 per cent) and Ottawa (43.9 per cent). Toronto is at 66.4 per cent.Article contentA decade ago, less than 40 per cent of median income was needed to cover housing. In the early 2000s, it was in the low 30 per cent range.Article contentArticle content“For your average British Columbian, and especially for a household in Vancouver, it is still not an affordable housing market,” Hogue said.Article contentRead More

It is 78.7 per cent in Victoria.Article contentIn B.C., and particularly in the Lower Mainland, housing affordability has been a significant concern for years. The provincial government has taken steps to try to cool housing prices, including introducing measures such as a foreign buyers’ tax and an empty homes tax.Article contentPremier David Eby’s NDP government has also taken control of municipal zoning, done away with public consultation on approved projects and will allow several units to be built on land previously designated for single family use in an effort to increase housing supply.Advertisement 1This advertisement has not loaded yet.Trending Saskatchewan firm's plan to export through Washington state instead of B.C. has David Eby fuming

noted that while there has also been a genuine effort to grow the housing supply, it is not anywhere strong enough to satisfy demand.Article content“This is going to take a very long time to address,” noted Hogue. “And, so, we urge all policymakers to keep at it and to continue to explore various ways to reduce construction costs.”Article contentHe said the federal government’s new Build Canada program could be helpful if it focuses on much-needed “deeply” affordable housing units.Article contentPrime Minister Mark Carney’s Liberal government announced that a new federal agency will be tasked with building more affordable homes with an initial budget of $13 billion, meant to offer financial incentives, bulk permitting and access to federal lands.Article contentThomas Davidoff, an economics professor at the University of B.C.’s Sauder School of Business, said even with housing affordability improving,  affordability remains “pretty” terrible.Article contentArticle contentThat’s led to a bid-ask spread between listing prices and what buyers are willing and able to pay, said Davidoff, director of the UBC centre for urban economics and real estate.Article content“And so we’ve got very, very slow transactions,” he said.Article contentDavidoff said policies enacted in B.C., including stricter regulations on Airbnb rentals, have helped cool housing prices.Article contentBut there is possibly more that could be done such as finding a way to tax high-value homes that have occupants not paying any income tax, he said.Article contentThat would also put pressure to have those homes come on the market and potentially be re-developed at higher densities, noted Davidoff.Article contentghoekstra@postmedia.comArticle contentx.com/gordon_hoekstraArticle contentShare this article
